verses.text: As Jesus and his disciples were on their way, he came to a village where a woman named Martha opened her home to him.
She had a sister called Mary, who sat at the Lord's feet listening to what he said.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 10:38
rsbNotes.text: 10:38 a village. Bethany, about two miles from Jerusalem (John 11:1).

verses.text: But Martha was distracted by all the preparations that had to be made. She came to him and asked, "Lord, don't you care that my sister has left me to do the work by myself? Tell her to help me!"
"Martha, Martha," the Lord answered, "you are worried and upset about many things,
but only one thing is needed. Mary has chosen what is better, and it will not be taken away from her."

rsbNotes.title: Luke 10:40–41
rsbNotes.text: 10:40, 41 Martha’s preparations may have been unnecessarily elaborate. Mary knew that listening to Jesus was an extraordinary opportunity, to be given preference over other concerns (see Mark 9:7).

verses.text: One day Jesus was praying in a certain place. When he finished, one of his disciples said to him, "Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples."

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:1
rsbNotes.text: 11:1 Lord, teach us to pray. Religious teachers were expected to teach their disciples how to pray.

verses.text: He said to them, "When you pray, say: "'Father, hallowed be your name, your kingdom come.
Give us each day our daily bread.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:2–4
rsbNotes.text: 11:2–4 This form of the “Lord’s Prayer” differs slightly from that in Matt. 6:9–13. In Matthew, the prayer is given in a sermon; here it is given in answer to a question.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:2
rsbNotes.text:
11:2 Father. This corresponds to the Aramaic Abba, the usual word for addressing a father in the family.

name. Names are representative of the person. The petition is that people will reverence God.

kingdom come. Jesus taught often about God’s kingdom, and the prayer asks for it to be established. See theological note “Prayer.”

verses.text: Forgive us our sins, for we also forgive everyone who sins against us. And lead us not into temptation. '"
Then he said to them, "Suppose one of you has a friend, and he goes to him at midnight and says, 'Friend, lend me three loaves of bread,
because a friend of mine on a journey has come to me, and I have nothing to set before him.'

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:4
rsbNotes.text: 11:4 forgive us . . . for we ourselves forgive. Sinners need the forgiveness of sins each day. If people do not forgive others they are not in a condition to receive forgiveness themselves.

verses.text: "Then the one inside answers, 'Don't bother me. The door is already locked, and my children are with me in bed. I can't get up and give you anything.'

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:7
rsbNotes.text: 11:7 In a one-room house the whole family would sleep on a raised platform, and for one person to get up would disturb them all.

verses.text: I tell you, though he will not get up and give him the bread because he is his friend, yet because of the man's boldness he will get up and give him as much as he needs.
"So I say to you: Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened to you.
For everyone who asks receives; he who seeks finds; and to him who knocks, the door will be opened.
"Which of you fathers, if your son asks for a fish, will give him a snake instead?
Or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:8
rsbNotes.text: 11:8 Friendship is not enough to make him get up, but persistence is.

verses.text: If you then, though you are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father in heaven give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!"

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:13
rsbNotes.text: 11:13 you . . . evil. Universal sinfulness is presupposed.
